texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: SSH key authentication  makes it easier to secure SSH servers and it opens the door to automation with projects such as  Ansible . However, working with encrypted SSH keys becomes tedious when you have several of them for different services. This is where an SSH agent can help!
texts.text: SSH key authentication  makes it easier to secure SSH servers and it opens the door to automation with projects such as  Ansible . However, working with encrypted SSH keys becomes tedious when you have several of them for different services. This is where an SSH agent can help!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: But before we talk about SSH agents:
texts.text: But before we talk about SSH agents:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Padme meme where she asks Anakin about encrypting his ssh keys
texts.text: Padme meme where she asks Anakin about encrypting his ssh keys

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I won't tell anyone, but if you happen to have unencrypted SSH keys laying around (which I'm sure you don't), I'll give you a quick primer on encrypting them. But you surely won't need these instructions. I'll do it anyway.
texts.text: I won't tell anyone, but if you happen to have unencrypted SSH keys laying around (which I'm sure you don't), I'll give you a quick primer on encrypting them. But you surely won't need these instructions. I'll do it anyway.

texts.orig: , then you have an unencrypted key. If it says
texts.text: , then you have an unencrypted key. If it says

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: instead, your private key is already encrypted. You can proceed through the prompts to set the password on the key.
texts.text: instead, your private key is already encrypted. You can proceed through the prompts to set the password on the key.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: One thing you quickly notice when you have a fleet of encrypted SSH keys is that you are constantly entering passwords. That's tedious. Instead, an agent helps you enter a password for a key one time per session. Every time to use the key after that first time, the agent steps in to help. 🕵🏻
texts.text: One thing you quickly notice when you have a fleet of encrypted SSH keys is that you are constantly entering passwords. That's tedious. Instead, an agent helps you enter a password for a key one time per session. Every time to use the key after that first time, the agent steps in to help. 🕵🏻

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You ssh to another server using
texts.text: You ssh to another server using

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your ssh client hands over your public key to the remote server
texts.text: Your ssh client hands over your public key to the remote server

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your ssh client takes the request from the remote server and hands it to the agent
texts.text: Your ssh client takes the request from the remote server and hands it to the agent

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The agent signs the message for the client
texts.text: The agent signs the message for the client

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your client sends the signed message back to the server
texts.text: Your client sends the signed message back to the server

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are some really important things to note here:
texts.text: There are some really important things to note here:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The agent holds the key or certificate in an unencrypted state in memory
texts.text: The agent holds the key or certificate in an unencrypted state in memory

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The agent doesn't write anything to the disk
texts.text: The agent doesn't write anything to the disk

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your password is not stored in memory once the initial decryption with
texts.text: Your password is not stored in memory once the initial decryption with

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Communication happens over a Unix socket that is owned by only your user
texts.text: Communication happens over a Unix socket that is owned by only your user

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This setup is far better than entering passwords over and over again, but if you forget to use
texts.text: This setup is far better than entering passwords over and over again, but if you forget to use

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: GNOME Keyring  has been around for many years and it provides tons of helpful features. You can store secrets, certificates, and SSH keys in the keyring. The keyring prompts you for a password when you log in to unlock the keyring and it locks again on reboot or shutdown.
texts.text: GNOME Keyring  has been around for many years and it provides tons of helpful features. You can store secrets, certificates, and SSH keys in the keyring. The keyring prompts you for a password when you log in to unlock the keyring and it locks again on reboot or shutdown.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It also provides ssh-agent functionality with a key difference: when it asks you for your SSH key password one time, it stores it for the next time. That means no
texts.text: It also provides ssh-agent functionality with a key difference: when it asks you for your SSH key password one time, it stores it for the next time. That means no

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: doom loops like I talked about earlier. You run
texts.text: doom loops like I talked about earlier. You run

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to connect to a server, get prompted for the key's password, and that's it. That key won't need to be decrypted again as long as your session is active.
texts.text: to connect to a server, get prompted for the key's password, and that's it. That key won't need to be decrypted again as long as your session is active.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's look at the options for
texts.text: Let's look at the options for

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
❯ gnome-keyring-daemon --help
Usage:
  gnome-keyring-daemon [OPTION…] - The Gnome Keyring Daemon

Help Options:
  -h, --help                              Show help options

Application Options:
  -s, --start                             Start a dameon or initialize an already running daemon.
  -r, --replace                           Replace the daemon for this desktop login environment.
  -f, --foreground                        Run in the foreground
  -d, --daemonize                         Run as a daemon
  -l, --login                             Run by PAM for a user login. Read login password from stdin
  --unlock                                Prompt for login keyring password, or read from stdin
  -c, --components=pkcs11,secrets,ssh     The optional components to run
  -C, --control-directory                 The directory for sockets and control data
  -V, --version                           Show the version number and exit.
texts.text:
❯ gnome-keyring-daemon --help
Usage:
  gnome-keyring-daemon [OPTION…] - The Gnome Keyring Daemon

Help Options:
  -h, --help                              Show help options

Application Options:
  -s, --start                             Start a dameon or initialize an already running daemon.
  -r, --replace                           Replace the daemon for this desktop login environment.
  -f, --foreground                        Run in the foreground
  -d, --daemonize                         Run as a daemon
  -l, --login                             Run by PAM for a user login. Read login password from stdin
  --unlock                                Prompt for login keyring password, or read from stdin
  -c, --components=pkcs11,secrets,ssh     The optional components to run
  -C, --control-directory                 The directory for sockets and control data
  -V, --version                           Show the version number and exit.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You'll notice that the default set of components includes
texts.text: You'll notice that the default set of components includes

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: for the ssh-agent functionality. However, Fedora handles things a little differently by default:
texts.text: for the ssh-agent functionality. However, Fedora handles things a little differently by default:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
❯ rpm -ql gnome-keyring | grep user   
/usr/lib/systemd/user/gnome-keyring-daemon.service
/usr/lib/systemd/user/gnome-keyring-daemon.socket

❯ cat /usr/lib/systemd/user/gnome-keyring-daemon.service
[Unit]
Description=GNOME Keyring daemon

Requires=gnome-keyring-daemon.socket

[Service]
Type=simple
StandardError=journal
ExecStart=/usr/bin/gnome-keyring-daemon --foreground --components="pkcs11,secrets" --control-directory=%t/keyring
Restart=on-failure

[Install]
Also=gnome-keyring-daemon.socket
WantedBy=default.target
texts.text:
❯ rpm -ql gnome-keyring | grep user   
/usr/lib/systemd/user/gnome-keyring-daemon.service
/usr/lib/systemd/user/gnome-keyring-daemon.socket

❯ cat /usr/lib/systemd/user/gnome-keyring-daemon.service
[Unit]
Description=GNOME Keyring daemon

Requires=gnome-keyring-daemon.socket

[Service]
Type=simple
StandardError=journal
ExecStart=/usr/bin/gnome-keyring-daemon --foreground --components="pkcs11,secrets" --control-directory=%t/keyring
Restart=on-failure

[Install]
Also=gnome-keyring-daemon.socket
WantedBy=default.target

texts.text: Let's reload the systemd user units and start the service:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
❯ systemctl daemon-reload --user
❯ systemctl enable --now --user gnome-keyring-daemon 
❯ systemctl status --user gnome-keyring-daemon
● gnome-keyring-daemon.service - GNOME Keyring daemon
     Loaded: loaded (/home/major/.config/systemd/user/gnome-keyring-daemon.service; enabled; vendor preset: disabled)
     Active: active (running) since Fri 2022-08-05 10:34:55 CDT; 4h 2min ago
TriggeredBy: ● gnome-keyring-daemon.socket
   Main PID: 63261 (gnome-keyring-d)
      Tasks: 5 (limit: 38353)
     Memory: 2.9M
        CPU: 533ms
     CGroup: /user.slice/user-1000.slice/user@1000.service/app.slice/gnome-keyring-daemon.service
             ├─ 63261 /usr/bin/gnome-keyring-daemon --foreground --components=pkcs11,secrets,ssh --control-directory=/run/user/1000/keyring
             └─ 63789 /usr/bin/ssh-agent -D -a /run/user/1000/keyring/.ssh

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: GNOME Keyring "just works" for 99% of my tasks, but sometimes I want to adjust a key or read a secret quickly. For that, give  Seahorse  a try. It's a graphical application that gives you access to everything GNOME Keyring stores and you can quickly lock your keyring at any time. The  Arch documentation on GNOME Keyring  also has plenty of tips for more automation and how to handle corner cases.
texts.text: GNOME Keyring "just works" for 99% of my tasks, but sometimes I want to adjust a key or read a secret quickly. For that, give  Seahorse  a try. It's a graphical application that gives you access to everything GNOME Keyring stores and you can quickly lock your keyring at any time. The  Arch documentation on GNOME Keyring  also has plenty of tips for more automation and how to handle corner cases.
